speaker: JL
transcript: Yeah. That strikes me as an interesting direction. Other other ideas around that? I mean, actually one one thing we could do is I think some of you are much more sort of coming from this research area. I know Jenny you and and Vic have have been working in this area. Um but and you explained a little bit about what you're doing. Um but David, uh are you also you're also working really in this area? Is that right?

speaker: DK
transcript: Uh yeah, I am. So I mentioned uh this uh work on sort of electrochemical pH swing as a way of doing CO2 separation. Um I'll say that the well, a couple things maybe, but in terms of the the one minute sort of idea or thing I'm thinking about, um you know, one thing I'll just throw out there is sort of thinking about ways of building sort of multifunctional uh either interfaces or materials that that sort of satisfy a number of the requirements that you need for CO2 separation, especially from air. So, um you know, so you you if you're doing say CO2 capture from air, you want something that's the oxygen that's not uh sort of sensitive to oxygen. Um you also want ideally something that's non-volatile. So if if you're doing this in an organic solvent, you're going to have issues with solvent loss. Um and then you want something that's uh redox active or that sort of responds to an electric field or potential. Um it will capture CO2 in one state and releases in another. And I'm curious as to whether it it makes any sense and you know, maybe in in typically what you would do is you pick the solvent and then you pick the active material and you sort of mix the two together, you know, you sort of build your system from there. Um I'm curious whether it makes sense to also think about trying to do or make sort of multifunctional sorbents that would fulfill a number of these requirements simultaneously. So for example, you start with uh like an ionic liquid, for example, which would not where you wouldn't have as much of an issue with uh volatility. And that is sort of your backbone and then you sort of build on top of that some sort of functionality or something either redox active or electric field responsive that does your that does sort of the switching uh sort of CO2 reversible CO2 binding release component. Um so I'm just sort of that's sort of what I'm I'm thinking about. Um is is whether you could build these sort of chemical uh these sort of new material systems and then you you you know, you put that in like a reactor um and one could then think about how effective it actually works in a in a real system, but yeah, that's that's one thought.

annotations.present new idea: DK proposes the idea of building multifunctional interfaces or materials for CO2 separation, especially from air, which satisfy multiple requirements simultaneously, such as being insensitive to oxygen, non-volatile, and redox active or responsive to an electric field.
annotations.expand on existing idea: DK elaborates on the idea of multifunctional materials by suggesting the use of an ionic liquid as a backbone and building on top of it redox active or electric field responsive functionality for CO2 capture and release.
annotations.explain or define term or concept: DK explains the requirements for CO2 separation from air, including insensitivity to oxygen, non-volatility, and redox activity or responsiveness to an electric field.
annotations.ask clarifying question: DK questions whether it makes sense to create multifunctional sorbents that fulfill multiple requirements for CO2 separation simultaneously.

speaker: JL

speaker: BG
transcript: Yeah, I um and shall would know this. So I actually have a publication dated from like five years ago, I think, um on electrochemically mediated CO2 separations using ionic liquids and using quinones as redox active carriers. Uh I mean exactly the same reasons you just mentioned, they are non-volatile. um and we can have appreciable amount of quinone solubility and and the right ionic liquids. And we can also uh improve the selectivity for CO2 and suppress it for oxygen to improve the sensitivity. But ultimately the redox active carrier is um you know, can be sensitive to oxygen and not necessarily maybe the electrolyte itself. But the um I think the main one of the main problems is um the ionic liquids are viscous, no matter you know, how you design them, they are going to be end up, you know, more viscous than your aqueous systems. And that's one challenge. And that kind of uh I think leads us into what kind of reactor designs can we have? Um I I yeah, I I think that's where I'll stop.

I I mean, it could still be a problem and water could start to become a problem too for that, but if it's N minus, it should probably be basic enough to deprotonate water. That could be an issue, but um, yeah.

speaker: JL
transcript: I'd I'd like to push those of you thinking along these lines a little bit. Um, you you're thinking a lot about thermodynamics here, but if you're doing a negative emissions um science um proposal and suggesting capture from air, a lot of it's about kinetics. It's an extraction from an unbelievably dilute mixture and uh it's all about the kinetics and interface and liquids have a real problem there. Uh, you know, how do you interface the gas of the air uh with a liquid and get good uptake? Um, so be sure to I I would encourage you to think about that as well when you come up with um new new proposal ideas.

speaker: AT
transcript: So I've got a question about that. So I mean I've used these type of MEA setups and the gas diffusion layer on that. I've kind of thought about that. Is it ever integrated in with porous materials or hierarchical materials to enhance transport in that? Um, or is that not even the rate limiting step, you know? What's what's the slow step in getting, you know, the CO2 to the actual catalyst surface or whatnot?

ask clarifying question: The user asks clarifying questions about the integration of gas diffusion layers with porous materials in MEA setups and the rate-limiting step in CO2 transport to the catalyst surface.
The user asks if the gas diffusion layer is integrated with porous materials and what the rate limiting step is for CO2 transport.

explain or define term or concept: The user explains their understanding of MEA setups and gas diffusion layers to provide context for their question.

speaker: FB
transcript: I think it depends on the concentration, right? I mean, if you have sort of pure CO2, you know, convectively transported over a porous layer, you know, then kinetics are probably going to be a problem will be your problem. If you're talking about 400 parts per million and maybe of a blower, but maybe it's just sort of natural diffusion, then I I tend to think that transport is going to be your problem. Um, almost immediately, right? Even if, you know, I think, you know, by the time you get your kinetic rate going, you're going to run out of material, right? So I do think that there is an interesting need for, can you make, and Andrew, this might be what you're getting at, active materials that have, you know, some sort of hierarchical structure that will preferentially drive CO2 or increase the CO2 flux to the surface. And can you do that through either hierarchical structure or maybe some CO2 polymers or something like that that can kind of continue to drive the thing in there. Um, as opposed to just relying on, you know, simple diffusive transport.

transcript: I think it's not ridiculous. I don't remember the group name, but I know there's a research group at the UK who does this kind of separation and the CO2 concentration increase. The first step is to let the air pass through the membrane, and then after that, just reduce the highly concentrated CO2. So I think it's not a ridiculous idea at all.

speaker: JL
transcript: I would warn that traditional membranes, the driving force is concentration gradient. And if your concentration on the air side is 410 ppm. It's really tough. Traditionally, why we use membranes for high pressure gas mixture separations and absorptive type separations for really low pressure mixtures. Along those lines though, I mean, there may be other ways of thinking about using membranes. I mean, I think the objective here is to think about some really crazy new directions. So I don't want to shut down that. I'm not saying that. I'm just saying what traditional membrane problems would be.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: JL explains the driving force behind traditional membranes and their limitations with low-pressure mixtures like air, defining the concentration gradient principle and its implications for CO2 capture.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: JL supports his explanation by stating the typical use cases of membranes (high-pressure gas mixtures) and absorption methods (low-pressure mixtures) based on established practices.
annotations.encourage particpatioin: Despite outlining the challenges, JL encourages exploring unconventional membrane applications for CO2 capture, promoting further brainstorming and idea generation ('think about some really crazy new directions').

speaker: AT
transcript: Simona Lagori is in this meeting, and she does metallic membrane work for these type of high pressure separations, but it works based on dissociative separation inside the metal. And then, of course, you still need your overall concentration gradient to drive it, but it's a potential interesting area.

annotations.provide_supporting_evidence: Andrew provides supporting evidence by mentioning Simona Lagori's expertise in metallic membrane work for high-pressure separations, which is relevant to the ongoing discussion about CO2 separation.
annotations.explain_or_define_term_or_concept: Andrew explains the concept of dissociative separation within the metal membrane, clarifying the mechanism of separation.
annotations.acknowledge_contribution: Andrew acknowledges Simona Lagori's presence and expertise in the meeting, recognizing her potential contribution to the discussion.

speaker: JY
transcript: Jimmy, I wanted to add something that was on my list of things that I was thinking about during our quiet time, and that was, do we have to release it in all cases, right? So many of us in this room work on CO2 reduction. So one of the things that we've thought about is instead of reducing CO2, let's reduce the alkox. It would be an alkyl carbonate or carbamate, right? These are the products of CO2 capture with amines and hydroxides or alkoxides, respectively. And if we could just directly reduce it from there, that's a solution. And I would argue that some of the CO2 reduction alkaline cells basically do that, right? Because you're probably not reducing directly CO2, but you're reducing bicarbonate or carbonate at those pHs. And so I think that is an interesting approach, and so sort of just reshifting our thinking about CO2 reduction to reducing bound CO2 to some of these capture agents directly. And then related to that, I realized there's no geochemist in the room, but I know that in sequestration, right? There's certain minerals that are, this is my limited knowledge, that are stable to bury underground. And so can we electrochemically generate the precursors to these minerals to then directly synthesize them, capture, and then just bury that? And so those are just some of my thoughts, is that maybe we don't want to regenerate, we just want to make the product directly from the CO2 that's captured.

present new idea: JY presents the idea of reducing captured CO2 directly without releasing it, by reducing alkox, alkyl carbonate, or carbamate, and electrochemically generating precursors to stable minerals for sequestration and burial.
explain or define term or concept: JY explains that alkox, alkyl carbonate, and carbamate are products of CO2 capture with amines, hydroxides, and alkoxides, respectively, and mentions that certain minerals are stable for underground burial in sequestration.
provide supporting evidence: JY supports the idea of reducing bound CO2 by arguing that some CO2 reduction alkaline cells already reduce bicarbonate or carbonate at certain pHs.
ask clarifying question: JY poses the question of whether CO2 needs to be released in all cases, prompting a shift in thinking about CO2 reduction.

And is there any, and this is really a question to the room, is there any interest in selectively separating the carbonate rather than you're just doing a simple pH swing somehow electrochemically or chemically? And then can you, would it be useful to separate the carbonate selectively and then use that?

speaker: DK
transcript: One thing you could do with the carbonate is precipitate it. But then it, then you have a solid and then it depends on what you want to use it for. So maybe some sort of building material perhaps, then you know, then the application changes entirely. But for example, carbon engineering was mentioned, and they basically do this process where they have CO2 react with hydroxide, and then they precipitate the, precipitate a solid with calcium carbonate. But perhaps you could go to some other solid products, not solid calcium carbonate, but solid something else, which is potentially more useful than calcium carbonate. But one of the things I always thought, well, with some of the mineralization stuff is that, okay, you make a, you take the CO2 out, and now it's a solid that you can easily dispose of. But can you make a solid that's as useful, if not more, than some of the traditional products of CO2 reduction, electro reduction? That's an open question.

speaker: JV
transcript: I know. I know. I've been inspired. It's just a lot of great conversation. So I guess two main topics. One, David just touched on on basically CO2 conversion or capture into solids. And then another point, the solid state chemist and me immediately starts thinking about, well, if I wanted to give a surface to Phil or to Jenny so they could do their reactions, what would it be? And I'm guessing whether or not if there's an opportunity here for nitrite-based porous or nitrite-based moths or nitrite-based types of materials that can perhaps give us the opportunity to create that amine that we've been talking about. I mean, there's been some success. I'm not sure if we are all convinced of the success of doing nitrogen reduction using nitrite-based materials. And then that sort of leads me to perhaps a super off idea of how about if we could, we know that flue gas has a lot of nitrogen in there and very little CO2. So who knows if we could like have a double whammy here where we do CO2 recovery of flue gas on the nitrite surface that will take the majority of the nitrogen of the flue gas and convert it

Um can we think about materials that would like have some induced entropic effects that would drive uh let's say the regeneration of CO2. I mean apart from enthalpic effects we can also have you know the entropic effects. Um and related to this, you know, we also discussed about these redux active CO2 carriers or redux active molecules, nucleophile. Um how about um designing the solvent around it. So you know this reduction potentials was too negative. I think um Jenny mentioned that. Well, I think we can design the interaction between these molecules with the environment to shift those potentials. So for example, I mean since I work with ionic liquids and deep eutectic solvents, I'm thinking about like hydrogen bonded systems that can interact with these species and shift the redox potentials so that you are in a better place and not like driving some other unwanted side reactions. Um and that has some entropy theme underneath it. Um I think those are the things that I thought about. And another thing is um we have worked with like encapsulated ionic liquids. So these had um these had graphene oxide material in its shell. So we thought okay, we have a conductive uh you know shell material. And initially we thought that we can use it at like energy storage, but it was kind of a naive idea because these are um you know, um kind of encapsulated liquids and they don't feel any voltage uh distribution. But in the context of CO2 capture and conversion or regeneration, um they can actually work as electrode materials where the ionic liquid or the core material can serve as like CO2 reservoirs. So you don't have to worry about um you know, have to bring CO2 to uh to the electrode surface. Um I mean you can tell me if it's a crazy idea but um something that that I think is something that we thought about in the past and kind of um you know, fits into this discussion I think.

present new idea: The speaker suggests exploring induced entropic effects in materials for CO2 regeneration, designing solvents around redox-active CO2 carriers to shift reduction potentials, and using encapsulated ionic liquids as electrode materials with CO2 reservoirs.
expand on existing idea: The speaker builds upon the prior discussion of thermodynamics and kinetics by focusing on entropic effects and their potential role in CO2 regeneration.
provide supporting evidence: The speaker mentions their work with ionic liquids and deep eutectic solvents as a basis for suggesting hydrogen-bonded systems to shift redox potentials.
ask clarifying question: The speaker implicitly seeks feedback on the feasibility of using encapsulated ionic liquids as electrode materials by asking if it's a crazy idea.
encourage particpatioin: The speaker invites feedback by asking for opinions on their ideas.

speaker: JV
transcript: Yeah, I've thought a little bit about it uh sort of trying to to up to take advantage of potential confinement effects by doing, you know, uh doing heterostructured materials where you have perhaps a core shell and then inside of inside of or perhaps a hollow conductive uh particle and then inside you have an active material that it's going to perhaps uh uh uh react with CO2 and then you have your conductive core to potentially help you do uh your your confinement. So I've thought about it in in in from the from this uh CO2 uh CO2 electrochemical conversion uh standpoint of view, but I think it it might be analogous uh to you know, to CO2 capture if we could get the CO2, you know, to to to be in close proximity to these uh heterostructures.

annotations.expand on existing idea: Jesus expands on the previous discussions of CO2 capture and conversion by suggesting the use of heterostructured materials with core-shell or hollow conductive particles to enhance CO2 capture through confinement effects, similar to their use in electrochemical conversion.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: Jesus supports his idea by mentioning his own prior thoughts and work on heterostructured materials for CO2 electrochemical conversion and suggests its analogous application to CO2 capture.

speaker: FB
transcript: Well, I had an idea. I I had an idea that kind of riffs off what you were saying. When you started to talk about encapsulation, I started to think about emulsions. So I think nano emulsions, things like that, right? You could imagine that you could have excuse me, an emulsion where you have let's say uh I think as Jesus was mentioning, um you know, redox active materials on the outside of that emulsion, right? That come you contact with an electrode surface, you reduce that emulsion, you know, and then that emulsion wanders off and grabs CO2. All the CO2 is sucked inside of that emulsion and then either you can store it and use it for later. Um you might react it as I think Jesus was suggesting and it becomes an emotion full of some product that you might want to use for later or you can figure out a way to sort of reverse that emulsion and and kick the CO2 out either way. And that might be a super cool way to use encapsulation.

annotations.present new idea: FB proposes a new idea of using nanoemulsions with redox-active materials on the outside to capture and potentially react with CO2, riffing off the previous discussion of encapsulation.
annotations.expand on existing idea: FB expands on the idea of encapsulation by suggesting the use of nanoemulsions as a specific implementation.
annotations.explain or define term or concept: FB explains the concept of nanoemulsions and how they could function in CO2 capture and conversion.
annotations.acknowledge contribution: FB acknowledges Jesus's earlier mention of redox-active materials and incorporates it into their idea.

speaker: BG
transcript: Yeah, I think that's really nice. I think it also overcomes some of the transport problems that we uh briefly discussed because you wouldn't have a much flowing dispersing uh fluid. Yeah, I mean as long as you sort of have these I think the trouble with the transport is always 2D versus 3D, right? You know, like if you're trying to flux to a surface that stinks as compared to trying to you know flux through a three-dimensional system. So you can imagine if this emulsion you could then hopefully like get gas fluxing through it, right? Um and then you only use the 2D surface for grabbing electrons or or throwing them back. Mhm.

annotations.expand on existing idea: BG expands on FB's idea of emulsions by highlighting how they address transport problems by creating a 3D system for gas flux, rather than a 2D surface.

speaker: JY
transcript: I was curious about that um when you I don't exactly understand emotions, but I was thinking about uh Phil Jessup's like switchable ionic liquids or solvents and would it be I don't I guess I have to read more about that, but would it be possible to put redox switches on that so that in one state it would be more likely to absorb and in another it would release. speaker: BG
transcript: Okay.

speaker: FB
transcript: A lot of times when you think about technology advancement, you know, while direct air capture might be the ultimate goal, it's unlikely that the first technology is going to be able to go after that. The nice thing about electrochemical technologies as compared to say thermochemical technologies that is it you could be more effective when you're smaller, right? Thermochemical technologies usually make a lot of hay when you're really large and can take advantage of sort of heat integration and infrastructure, right? And so, you know, one of the things is, are there applications that you could think about where electrochemical technologies or some of the things we're talking about here are uniquely positioned because I assume that in cabin capture, it's really just like, you know, alkaline pellets, right? Um, you know, Apollo 13 or something like that, right? And you know, if that's true, then the question would be, are there opportunities to kind of say, are there, can we sort of walk down the technology curve from let's say carbon capture to maybe in cabins to maybe buildings to eventually direct air capture?
screenshare_content: Jesus Velazqui is sharing his screen, which shows a slide with a chemical reaction diagram. The diagram depicts the conversion of CO2 and H2 into CH3OH. No changes are made to the content within this segment.

annotations.present new idea: FB proposes a new idea of focusing on smaller-scale applications of electrochemical technologies for CO2 capture, such as in-cabin capture, before scaling up to direct air capture.
annotations.expand on existing idea: FB expands on the existing discussion of CO2 capture technologies by contrasting electrochemical and thermochemical approaches and their scalability.
annotations.ask clarifying question: FB asks a clarifying question about the potential applications of electrochemical technologies for CO2 capture in different contexts, such as in-cabin, buildings, and eventually direct air capture.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: FB supports his argument by mentioning alkaline pellets used in in-cabin capture, referencing Apollo 13 as an example.
annotations.propose decision: FB proposes the decision to explore applications of electrochemical technologies for CO2 capture in smaller-scale contexts before tackling direct air capture.

speaker: BG
transcript: Yeah, so actually it's a very interesting project. Um, it's not as challenging as direct air capture, but nonetheless, it has other challenges. So right now, uh they use Zeolites. So it's essentially a thermal regeneration. So uh there are problems with Zeolites though, um that I don't have to get into, but they are interested in uh sorbents uh as opposed to Zeolites. And you know, in cabin, you want something non-volatile, kind of kind of benign solvent. And um the good thing about we can think about also like pressure swing and and you know, in space vacuum is kind of free. So, uh there are some advantages on that front. But I think they are also interested ultimately, you know, maybe like scavenging oxygen out of CO2 like through a Bosch type of reaction. Um, but yeah, right now they are uh thermally regenerating at much higher cost actually for the Zeolites. Uh and they also have to scrub, they they have to um, you know, dry the air first because Zeolites are not really stable um with moisture. Um, I don't know. I think I missed your question.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: BG explains the current state of in-cabin CO2 capture technology, including the use of zeolites and thermal regeneration, and the challenges associated with them.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: BG supports their point about the challenges of zeolites by mentioning their instability with moisture and the need to dry the air first.

annotations.expand on existing idea: BG builds on the discussion of alternative CO2 capture methods by suggesting pressure swing and the potential of scavenging oxygen from CO2 through a Bosch-type reaction, leveraging the vacuum of space.

speaker: FB
transcript: No, I guess it was kind of around and it was keying off of what you said, but it was for everybody, which is, you know, are we jumping the gun going directly to direct air capture? Are there other opportunities along the way down the CO2 concentration curve, for lack of a better word, where we could add a tremendous amount of value in terms of, you know, negative carbon emissions. Um, and what might those be?

annotations.ask clarifying question: FB asks if the group is prematurely focusing on direct air capture and if there are other valuable negative emissions opportunities with higher CO2 concentrations, prompting further discussion and brainstorming.
annotations.encourage particpatioin: FB directs the question to the entire group, inviting broader participation and diverse perspectives on alternative applications beyond direct air capture.

speaker: DK
transcript: So, so one thing that came to mind, comes to mind for me as well. Yeah, so direct capture is hard. You see you're taking, you know, you're capturing from 400 BPM and you want to go to one bar because you want to see crystal or uh convert. Um, if instead you still capture from air, but your requirement was only to go to like two or three percent, let's say, that concentration of CO2 would be useful if you were doing something like algae. So, like algae actually don't need to go all the way to 100%. If you if you get up to a couple percent, even 5%, um, they they can be pretty effective. So you can, you know, use it to do things like algae, um, like uh like fuels for aviation fuel or whatever. You can, you know, you can there's a whole bunch of other work engineering algae to make particular um products. But but that could be sort of another like a sort of a step down um the curve where you are doing CO2 capture. Um and it is useful uh because, you know, we're not going to get electric planes anytime soon. Um, but you're not you're not, you know, you don't have this massive concentration factor like 2500 or whatever it is. So that might be another way.

annotations.present new idea: DK proposes an alternative approach to CO2 capture, suggesting capturing from air to a concentration of 2-3% for algae use, rather than the more difficult direct air capture to one bar.
annotations.expand on existing idea: Building on the discussion of CO2 capture and utilization, DK expands on the idea by suggesting a less demanding concentration target for specific applications like algae-based fuel production.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: DK supports the idea of using lower CO2 concentrations for algae by stating that algae don't need 100% CO2 for effective utilization.
annotations.explain or define term or concept: DK explains the challenge of direct air capture, highlighting the large concentration factor required to go from 400 ppm in air to one bar for conversion.

speaker: JY
transcript: I have a question related to what you were saying about scale. Um, and I know some of you guys work with flow batteries too, which is probably related. Is there um an optimal scale at which to run these electrochemical processes? And is it, can you can you scale it down without any loss uh indefinitely? Like what's what what sizes matter?

annotations.ask clarifying question: JY asks about the optimal scale and the feasibility of scaling down electrochemical processes without loss, based on the prior discussion about scale and flow batteries.
annotations.explain or define term or concept: JY is seeking clarification on the concept of scale in the context of electrochemical processes and its relationship to flow batteries.

speaker: FB
transcript: It depends on the process a little bit, um, and it depends upon where your cost is in the process. So, for example, you could sort of think of it as flow batteries are an easy example because you can separate power and energy. And so if you want an energy intensive application, the cost is dominated by what's in your tank. Um, if you have a power dominant application, it's dominated by what the what it cost you to make the reactor. Uh in these kind of systems, it's a bit different, right? And it would probably the way you'd want to think about it is throughput, right? So it's kind of what is the capital cost of your reactor? And then how much CO2 can you put through it because that's how you're going to make money, right? Um, and so that's how you should think about it. I mean, capital cost is important because, you know, bank ability, like someone's got to pay for the thing, right? And so if you think about like the first solar cells, they they kind of stunk, right? But they're still working and they're small and you can put them on your roof, right? Um, and so, you know, if for electrochemical systems, you could build at that sort of scale, local residential scale, and that allows you to do a lot more learning um as you go, and allows you also to make smaller products, which mean that there's less opportunities for for screw ups and a lot less money involved. Um, for a lot of sort of, you know, the larger scale systems like I guess carbon engineering, I mean, I think that system is is is pretty big in the base case. And I don't know how many of them they've built. I'm not so I've seen a lot of pretty pictures, but I don't know if I've actually seen a plant. Um, and so there's some some something about like, well, who's paying for this? How confident are you that this is going to work? Yada yada yada, this kind of stuff, right? So I don't think electrochemical systems can be infinitely small for sure. Um, but you could be a lot smaller than thermochemical systems. And actually if you look at scaling analysis, thermochemical systems can beat out electrochemical systems at large enough scale, right? Just because of heat integration, we're really good at that. Um, but at smaller scales, um the tables turn.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: FB explains that the cost of energy-intensive applications is dominated by the tank contents, while power-dominant applications depend on reactor cost, and then introduces "throughput" as the key metric for CO2 capture systems.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: FB uses flow batteries and solar cells as examples to illustrate the concepts of power vs. energy intensive applications and scaling.
annotations.offer constructive criticism: FB suggests that focusing on smaller-scale electrochemical systems might be more practical and allow for more learning compared to large-scale thermochemical systems like Carbon Engineering, implicitly critiquing the current focus on large-scale projects.
annotations.expand on existing idea: Building on the discussion of CO2 capture methods, FB discusses the importance of scale and cost considerations for different electrochemical and thermochemical approaches.
